metadata.case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Proprietor of Mauza Bhivapur

facts.text: The respondent was a proprietor of mauza Bhivapur, Tehsil Umrer, District Nagpur.
Proprietary interest in the village was abolished by the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (M.P. 1 of 1951).

By virtue of s. 4 of the Act, all rights, titles and interests in pathways, village sites, hats, bazars and melas in Bhivapur vested in the State of Madhya Pradesh free from all encumbrances under s. 4(1)(a).
Under States Reorganisation Act, 1956, those rights vested in State of Bombay and then by Bombay Reorganisation Act, 1960 (11 of 1960) in State of Maharashtra.

Compensation proceedings in Revenue case No. 583/1-A-4/1950-51 before Compensation Officer, Umrer, decided on January 19, 1952: held 0.14 acres of land out of Khasra No. 61/1 (recorded as abadi wherein bazar is held) should be settled with respondent under s. 5(a).
On a portion of the land used for bazar, ottas and chabutras, with or without sheds, separated by passages, exist and belong to the respondent.
Land covered by ottas and chabutras on which sheds constructed were ordered settled with respondent.
Respondent contended that not only sheds and land thereunder but open uncovered ottas and chabutras and land appurtenant should be settled under s. 5(a); total area claimed 2.85 acres.
Appeal against Compensation Officer's order dismissed by Additional Commissioner of Land Reforms on March 28, 1952.
Respondent asked to remove ottas and chabutras.

Press note issued by Directorate of Information and Publicity, Govt. of MP on May 16, 1952: where ottas/chabutras constructed in brick/stone, allow to remain with ex-proprietors and settle land thereunder under s. 5(a); mud ones vest in State.
Govt. issued instructions to Deputy Commissioners on June 22, 1954 to give one month's notice to ex-proprietors to remove materials of ottas/chabutras other than those with sheds.
Notice issued to respondent on July 13, 1954.

Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 in Nagpur High Court, Misc. Petition No. 448 of 1954; judgment dated January 16, 1956 allowed petition, set aside orders of Compensation Officer, appellate authority, State Govt. order June 22, 1954 and notice July 13, 1954; directed State to settle entire Khasra No. 61/1 (12.85 acres) with respondent.
State sought certificate under Art. 133(1)(c), denied.
Special leave petition to Supreme Court under Art. 136; leave granted March 18, 1957.
Entire area of Khasra No. 61/1 is about 12.85 acres.

legal_issues.text: Whether ottas and chabutras (uncovered) fall within the term 'buildings' in s. 5(a) of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1950.
Whether the High Court erred in directing settlement of the entire Khasra No. 61/1 (12.85 acres) instead of only the area covered by structures and appurtenant land (2.85 acres).

petitioner_arguments.text: Ottas and chabutras cannot be regarded as buildings within s. 5(a); for a structure to be a building, it should have walls and a roof.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 5(a) MP Act 1950; Moir v. Williams; Morrison v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue; Samuel Small v. Parkway Auto Supplies

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in directing settlement of entire abadi area of 12.85 acres in Khasra No. 61/1 when market area claimed is only 2.85 acres.
Buildings in s. 5(a) are those in abadi excluding bazar area which vests in State under s. 4(1)(a); ottas/chabutras in bazar are integral part thereof.

respondent_arguments.text: Ottas and chabutras etc. are buildings within s. 5(a); State bound to settle land covered by them with ex-proprietors along with appurtenant land.
Conceded that High Court erred in directing entire 12.85 acres; respondent wants only 2.85 acres.

court_reasoning.text: s. 5(a) is exception to s. 4(1)(a); land on which bazar held is part of village abadi; buildings on such land fall within s. 5(a) and must be settled with ex-proprietor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Land on which the bazar is held is part of the village abadi land and, therefore, all buildings standing on such land would fall within s. 5(a).

court_reasoning.text: Ottas and chabutras are buildings as word should be given literal meaning as something which is built; where ex-proprietor spent money constructing within village site limits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The word buildings should, therefore, be given its literal meaning as something which is built.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents distinguish: meanings depend on context; ordinary meaning is something built; High Court right that even uncovered ottas/chabutras fall within term.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The natural or ordinary meaning to be given to the word Buildings, is something which has been built.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in directing entire Khasra 61/1; should settle only land covered by structures + appurtenant; precise area to be determined by revenue authorities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It would be sufficient to direct the Government to settle with the respondent the whole of the land covered by the structures as well as land appurtenant to those structures from out of Khasra No. 61/1.

holdings.text: Ottas and chabutras (even uncovered) fall within term 'buildings' in s. 5(a); land covered + appurtenant thereto to be settled with ex-proprietor.
Not entire Khasra No. 61/1 but only land covered by structures + appurtenant; area to be determined in settlement proceedings.

precedents_cited.relevance: Discussed meaning of 'building' as enclosures of brick/stone covered by roof, but depends on enactment and context.

precedents_cited.case_name: Morrison v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Buildings' means in narrower sense than structures; natural meaning is something built.

precedents_cited.case_name: Samuel Small v. Parkway Auto Supplies
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Building' denotes structure with walls and roof; context of restrictive covenant; does not assist appellants.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (M.P. 1 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of proprietary rights in State except buildings etc. in village site to be settled with ex-proprietor.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of vested rights from MP to Bombay.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Reorganisation Act, 1960 (11 of 1960)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of vested rights from Bombay to Maharashtra.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court petition and Supreme Court appeal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part: upheld High Court's view that ottas and chabutras are buildings under s. 5(a) but modified direction to settle only land covered by structures and appurtenant thereto (not entire Khasra No. 61/1), with precise area to be determined by revenue authorities.
outcome.relief_granted: Direction to State Government to settle with respondent the land covered by structures as well as appurtenant land from Khasra No. 61/1 on terms to be determined.

key_quotes.text: The word buildings should, therefore, be given its literal meaning as something which is built.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: even uncovered ottas and chabutras fall within the term building as used in s. 5(a) of the Act
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It would be sufficient to direct the Government to settle with the respondent the whole of the land covered by the structures as well as land appurtenant to those structures from out of Khasra No. 61/1.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final directional relief modifying High Court order
